document.title: Family Life Education Board of Education Guidelines and Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

24CF7429AE374ECB8265BE287C5FD2D9.description:
Factual information regarding the nature of sexually transmitted
infection, including human immuno-deficiency virus (HIV)/acquired immune deficiency
syndrome (AIDS), is introduced. Other diseases referred to include but are not limited to
Chlamydia, Genital Herpes, Gonorrhea, Human Papilloma Virus (HPV), and Syphilis.

431409C3D8CB4522A91A520AA56C2DC4.description: The student will become aware of the existence of sexually transmitted infection.

55FA8257C3D4490590D933AC5B03BE49.description:
Emphasis is placed on the adverse effects of alcohol, drugs, and
tobacco on the body. This information is related to physical and emotional growth during
adolescence, including sexual development; to fetal development; and to any adverse
effects upon the family unit.

C899031E25354C6C9C29AE5781305BDC.description: The student will explain the effects of substance use and abuse on the body.

4583871AAF394270934F38356A765C24.description:
These situations may include walking alone, opening doors to
strangers, experiencing sexual abuse or incest, being influenced or coerced into selling
their bodies for financial gain, receiving obscene telephone calls or text messages, and
facing dangers found in shopping malls. Methods of self-protection and recognition and
reporting of threats are identified and stressed. The point is made, however, that most life
situations are not threatening.

AE2930EC61D647FCA1B9C53177117F63.description:
The student will recognize threatening or uncomfortable situations and how to react
to them.

C3C549A83CD0485FABFF23C97A62731B.description:
Discussion focuses on alternatives to situations such as rude
behavior, smoking, alcohol or drug use, theft, vandalism, violence, and premarital and
unwanted sexual relationships.

379E9A22B6D14423AD649A72424B0DE6.description:
The student will develop skill in saying "no" to any social behavior or activity that
he or she perceives as wrong for him or herself.

1E82A47A2DB04F2BA56DCEB09B458176.description:
Printed materials, advertising, television, wearing apparel,
Internet, movies, and music are discussed in relation to gender stereotyping and to the
avoidance of sexual exploitation, sexually explicit communication using electronic
means, and sexual violence. Students will understand the appropriate use of cell phones
and other social media. Students will understand how the media affects mental health
issues related to sexuality.

FEE4941FEB114FE6B3AA2188C08CDF99.description: The student will examine the messages from mass media related to sexuality.

8B9DDC54B4694FEE81F136EBF703C0BF.description:
The student can achieve this by defining the traditional and
changing roles, duties, and responsibilities of family members; by preparing for the
life- long adjustments required for his or her changing roles; and by describing the
emotional interactions involved in being a family member. Nontraditional roles of males
and females are discussed, and options for the lifelong goals of men and women are
presented.

54697CA33C4B4FC6B52D47AEBFA933EA.description:
The student will develop an increased understanding of the roles, duties, and
responsibilities of family members.

845604FC4D8545C19BC9FA1A83232044.description:
The teacher emphasizes the individual's contribution to accepting
responsibility, how this relates to group success or failure, and how opportunities for
leadership may be presented.

7FD3E408BF5D49CD95542FD555D3C293.description:
The student will recognize the importance of contributing to a constructive group
activity.

50CBED7203144E229B7AE241029C5879.description:
Discussion focuses on those bodily changes in puberty that
require special attention to cleanliness and their relationship to a positive self-concept and
acceptance from peers. Proper use of feminine hygiene products in relationship to
cleanliness is included.

7F0379F76F144267960041DC0C80A5B1.description: The student will describe the effects of personal hygiene on one's self-concept.

FCF40BEFEB2D4694B72116181FA76903.description:
The psychological, social, and physical consequences of
premarital sexual relations are discussed, as well as the benefits of postponing sexual
intercourse until one is physically and emotionally mature and has a positive, committed
marital relationship. The effects of premarital sex, including teenage pregnancy, infant
mortality, and sexually transmitted infections are emphasized, as well as the impact on
one's reputation, self-esteem, and mental health.

7293E5F483804516A2D005CC1D004745.description: The student will identify reasons for avoiding sexual activity prior to marriage.

8E7CBC5885244037B1F861541A8C1A60.description:
This objective is incorporated into the nutrition component for the
fifth-grade health curriculum.

AFDD3AED82B0465286BD77E4C4C9A224.description:
The student will realize the importance of nutrition for himself or herself and for
pregnant women who need to eat nutritious foods and avoid dangerous substances
while the baby is growing inside the uterus.

031114C73F6C4F34B01DBBED860113A1.description:
Physical changes that occur during puberty are summarized.
Topics included are nocturnal emissions and erections; menstruation; instability of
emotions, such as mood swings during puberty; development of a positive attitude toward
one's sexuality; and the relationship between changes during puberty and one's ability to
conceive and bear children.

487D2470D71748228D3E3D4F378AC8B2.description:
The student will recognize the relationship between the physical changes that occur
during puberty and the developing capacity for reproduction.

490AF1C0D2164AD1A5D630D104194E67.description:
Instruction includes the uniting of the sperm and the egg and the
development of the unborn child inside the uterus. The development of the baby at
different stages is illustrated. Emphasis is placed on the consequences of premarital
sexual activity. The importance of prenatal care is discussed also, as well as the profound
effects of drugs on the mother and developing child.

0C85433B6DB5470FB17950464B2A7228.description: The student will explain how human beings reproduce.

48685CF0D26C40E39D498EA3BD6D12A7.description:
Emphasis is placed on the male reproductive organs: penis,
testicles, scrotum, and urethra; and on the female reproductive organs: uterus, ovaries,
vagina, and fallopian tubes. The reproductive organs are explained in relation to total
human anatomy.

24626F8ADE2B428F851A872B0F05F0EE.description:
The student will identify the human reproductive organs in relation to the total
anatomy.

310BF3F0E93C4E8E98A62EF173EA9357.description:
The basic parts of the endocrine system (pituitary gland and
adrenal glands) and their functions are introduced.

474CCFBBEFEC4F0C82111620B769A466.description: The student will define the structure and function of the endocrine system.
